channel.title: Open Development Cambodia
channel.description: Sharing information about Cambodia and its development with the world.

item.title: Home
item.dc:creator: odc_admin
item.content:encoded:
Open Development Cambodia is an online hub compiling freely available data in a ‘one-stop shop’ to provide up-to-date information about Cambodia, using an ‘open data’ approach.

អង្គការ​ទិន្នន័យ​អំពី​ការ​អភិវឌ្ឍ​ (ODC)​ គឺជាមជ្ឈមណ្ឌល​ដែល​ធ្វើការ​នៅ​លើ​បណ្តាញ​អ៊ិ​ន​ធើ​ណិ​ត​ ដោយ​ប្រមូលផ្តុំ​ទិន្នន័យ​ដែល​មាន​ជា​សាធារណៈ​ និង​ផ្តល់ជូនដល់​សាធារណៈជន​​ដោយឥតគិតថ្លៃ នូវ​ព័ត៌មាន​ត្រឹមត្រូវ​ និង​ថ្មី​បំផុត​ អំពី​ប្រទេស​កម្ពុជា​ និង​ការ​អភិវឌ្ឍន៍​សង្គម​ និង​សេដ្ឋកិច្ច​របស់​ប្រទេស​នេះ​។​

item.title: Maps
item.dc:creator: odc_admin
item.content:encoded:
The ODC map page is dynamic page that can visualize the areas or Geography in Cambodia including:
  • Protected Areas,
  • Provincial, District and Commune Boundary and Villages Location,
  • Economic Land Concessions,
  • Concessions of Mining,
  • Hydropower,
  • Special Economic Zone,
  • Oil and Gas Blocks,
  • and other more

item.title: Laws & Regulations
item.dc:creator: odc_admin
item.content:encoded:
CONSTITUTION

Cambodia’s Constitution was adopted by the Constitutional Assembly on September 21, 1993. It is the supreme law of the Kingdom of Cambodia and organizes Cambodia’s government and institutions. All laws and regulations derive from the Constitution’s provisions and must conform to it.1 The Constitution addresses questions of sovereignty, the role and status of the king, the fundamental rights of the Khmer citizens, the economy, education, culture and social affairs, the functioning of the National Assembly, the Senate, congress and the government, the functioning of the judiciary, Constitutional Council and the administration. [expand title="Click here for more details about Cambodia's Constitution and Constitutional Council" swaptitle="Hide the details of Cambodia's Constitution and Constitutional Council"] Revision of the Constitution The Constitution can only be amended or revised when an initiative is undertaken. The king and the prime minister can submit an initiative on their own accord. The president of the National Assembly can also submit such an initiative, but only after the initiative was requested by at least one-fourth of the National Assembly.2 The revision or amendment must be enacted in a law passed by the assembly with a 2/3-majority vote. Revisions or amendments are prohibited if the country is in a state of emergency (a notion that is not legally defined), or if the amendment in question intends to affect the system of liberal and pluralistic democracy or the regime of the constitutional monarchy.3 The Constitution has been amended 5 times:
  • in 1994 (delegation of power from the king’s signature to the acting head of state)
  • 1999 (institution of the Senate)
  • 2001 (creation and conferring medals by the king)
  • 2005 (amendment of the quorum of the session and the adopting vote of the National Assembly and the Senate)
  • 2006 (amendment of quorum of the session and of the adopting vote of the National Assembly and the Senate).4
The Constitutional Council The Constitutional Council is composed of 9 members for a term of 9 years: 3 are appointed by the king, 3 by the National Assembly and 3 by the Supreme Council for the Magistracy. The Constitution also states that 3 members shall be replaced every 3 years.5 The Constitutional Council fulfills two missions: (1) Safeguard respect for the constitution and interpret its provisions and the laws passed by the National Assembly; and (2) Examine and decide on contested cases involving the election of National Assembly and Senate members.6 The Constitutional Council cannot take the initiative to decide upon the constitutionality of a law. The king, the president of the Senate, the president of the National Assembly, the prime minister, one-fourth of the senators or one-tenth of the National Assembly’s members are the only entities that may send the laws adopted by the National Assembly and definitively reviewed by the Senate to the Constitutional Council for examination before or after their promulgation.7 The control of the constitutionality can only occur at the demand of the legislature, the executive or the king. The competence of the council is limited to the examination of constitutionality of laws, meaning it is not allowed to control the constitutionality of all other forms of norms (decrees, sub-decrees, and so on). Citizens may question a law’s constitutionality and may question the constitutionally of any decision made by a state institution when engaged in a legal proceeding if they consider that a provision of a law or a decision of any institution violates any of his/her fundamental rights and liberties.8 When a party to a trial believes a law is unconstitutional, he raises what is called an interlocutory question before the court. First, the court has to rule if the request is well-founded. If the request is well-founded, the trial is suspended and the case is submitted to the Supreme Court. If the Supreme Court deems the case acceptable it will refer it to the Constitutional Council. The law does not give any instruction or criteria on how these entities shall determine the acceptability of a case. Since its creation in 1998, the Constitutional Council has received few petitions, and none has come from a party to a trial, meaning no interlocutory question has ever reached the Council. [/expand]

HIERARCHY OF LAWS AND REGULATIONS

Law and regulations are classified in order of importance. There are numerous legal norms adopted by the legislative and executive powers: Constitution, laws, decrees, decisions, and so on. There is a strict hierarchy between them, so that each norm of a lower level must conform with those of a higher value. This prevents conflict between norms. [expand title="Click here for Cambodia's categories of laws and regulations" swaptitle="Hide the details of Cambodia's categories of laws and regulations"] Constitution: The supreme law of the Kingdom of Cambodia International treaties: The king signs and ratifies international treaties and conventions after their approval by the National Assembly and the Senate. After such ratification, international treaties and conventions become laws and may be used as the basis for judicial decisions. (Article 26 of the Constitution) Chbab/law: Laws adopted by the National Assembly Kram and kret (royal kram and royal decree): Decrees issued under the name of the king in execution of his constitutional powers Anukret/sub-decree: Are signed by the prime minister after adoption by a cabinet meeting. In case the cabinet meeting has not adopted the sub-decree, countersignature by the minister(s) in charge is required. The prime minister can use this in execution of his own regulatory powers. Prakas/proclamations: Are issued by members of the government in execution of their own regulatory powers. Sechdei samrech/decision: Individual decision(s) made by the prime minister, minister or governor (prakas-deika), which are made in execution of his own regulatory powers Sarachor/circular: In general, a circular is issued by the prime minister as the head of government, and by a minister as an official of the relevant ministry either to explain or clarify legal regulatory measures or to provide instructions. Deka/provincial ordinance: Orders issued by a governor within the territorial limits of his province. Despite this hierarchy, laws and regulations often contradict each other. Since there is no power or entity in charge of overseeing or reviewing inconsistent laws and regulations, confusion often arises as to which law or regulation should be followed. [/expand]

THE LEGISLATIVE PROCESS

The National Assembly and the Senate share the legislative power.10 Senators, members of the National Assembly and the prime minister have the right to initiate legislation by making draft laws or proposed laws.11 The legislative process usually takes a few months to be completed. However, in cases of emergency the process is shortened and laws can be approved within days. Laws are enacted after an absolute majority (50% + 1) of the National Assembly votes to adopt the law.12 [expand title="Click here for more details about Cambodia's legislative process" swaptitle="Hide the details of Cambodia's legislative process"] Most of the texts that come into form are draft laws (initiative of the government). When the draft/proposed law is an initiative of the Senate, the National Assembly can propose amendments only if they do not reduce citizens’ income or increase the burden on people.13 A large proportion of laws are issued from the shortened procedure based on the invocation of a state of emergency, which means they are adopted within a few days and leave very little time for reflection or perfection of the law. For example, the Law on the Aggravating Circumstances of Crimes (2002), the Law on the Duration of Pre-trial Detention (1999), the Law on the Organization and Functioning of the Constitutional Council (1998) and the Labor Law (1997) were adopted through the emergency legislative process. When the National Assembly examines the request of modification made by the Senate, it can only decide on the provisions that have been proposed for modification by the Senate. It then either rejects the proposed modification(s), or adopts it entirely or partly.14 The process of sending the draft/proposed law back and forth between the Senate and the National Assembly must be completed within one month. This period is reduced to 10 days in the case of national budget and finance laws, and 2 days for an urgent law.15 When the Senate rejects the draft/proposed law (nullifying it), the National Assembly cannot take it into consideration for a second time before a period of one month has expired. This period is reduced to 15 days in case of national budget or finance laws, and 4 days if urgent.16 Promulgation occurs with the king’s signature. Laws enter into force in Phnom Penh 10 days after promulgation, and throughout the country 20 days after promulgation. However, if the law is declared urgent is shall enter into force throughout the country immediately.17 All laws shall be published in the Royal Gazette and announced throughout the country in accordance with the time frame set out above.18 [/expand]

THE JUDICIARY AND COURTS

The Cambodian judicial system is composed of courts of first instance, appeals courts, and a Supreme Court. According to article 128 of the Constitution, the judiciary is independent, guaranteeing and upholding impartiality and protecting the rights and freedoms of the citizens. The Constitution also states that judicial power should not be granted to the legislative or executive branches and should cover all lawsuits, including administrative ones. The Constitution of Cambodia leaves the functioning of the judiciary to be determined in a separate law. The law on the organization and the activities of the adjudicate courts was promulgated in 1993. Trials are conducted in the name of the Khmer citizens in accordance with the legal procedures and laws into force. Only judges have the right to adjudicate. A judge must fulfill this duty with strict respect of laws, wholeheartedly and conscientiously.19 Fair trial rights are embedded in a wide range of laws and procedural rules. The presumption of innocence, burden of proof, and rules governing the admissibility and exclusion of evidence are examples of codified fair trial rights afforded to all. [expand title="Click here for more details about Cambodia's judiciary and courts" swaptitle="Hide the details of Cambodia's judiciary and courts"] Courts provincial and Municipal Courts Provincial and municipal courts are located in the provinces and municipalities, and they have jurisdictional competence on the territory of each of those municipalities and provinces in civil, criminal, commercial, administrative and labor cases.20  In principle, municipal and provincial courts are divided into two departments: civil and criminal. However, in practice, as the number of judges is very limited, there is no clear separation between the departments and judges often handle both civil and criminal cases.21 Public prosecutors are attached to each court.22 Only the department of public prosecution has the right to file criminal lawsuits.23 Provincial and municipal courts are headed by a judge, and complemented by a prosecutor or a deputy prosecutor and a court clerk.24 A provincial or municipal court's judgment is made in the presence of the parties. Parties may appeal its decision within two (2) months from the date of the decision. Judgments by default (those made in the absence of the parties/party), allow for an opposition (refusal complaint) to filed within a period of 15 day, from the date of notification of the judgment. If upon the period permitted for opposition is expired, an appeal may then be made against the judgment within a period of 2 months.25 Appeals Court The Appeals Court, which is a higher court than municipal and provincial courts, is located in Phnom Penh. The Appeals Court has jurisdictional competence for the whole of Cambodia.26 Filling an appeal to the Appeals Court is not bound by any condition because there are no laws or guidelines specifying the grounds required for making an appeal. There is no mechanism to filter groundless or unreasonable appeals. There are no penalties for making unwarranted or vexatious appeals. Supreme Court The Supreme Court, located in Phnom Penh, is the highest court in Cambodia and the court of final instance. It is staffed with 12 judges and four prosecutors. The Supreme Court has competence to proceed with hearings on grievance complaints against judgments of the Appeals Court by considering questions only of law. The Supreme Court cannot consider questions of fact. Supreme Council for the Magistracy Articles 132 to 134 of the Constitution establishes the Supreme Council of Magistracy (SCM) to guarantee the independence and efficiency of the judiciary. It is composed of 9 members: the king as president, the Minister of Justice, the President of the Supreme Court, the Prosecutor General of the Supreme Court, the President of the Appeals Court, the Prosecutor of the Appeals Court, and three judges27. The SCM and the Minister of Justice have a major influence on judges at all levels: their power to appoint, to discipline, and to instruct judicial officials28 place judges and prosecutors in a subservient position.29 The SCM has been criticized for failing to fulfill its mandate based upon allegations of corruption, lack of independence and politicization.30 Military Court The Military Court sits outside of the normal court system. Established in 1981and located in Phnom Penh, it can only hear cases related to military offenses.31 The procedure of the Military Court is the same as the procedure of the provincial and municipal courts. Military offenses are those committed by military members in the armed forces and those offenses that concern military discipline or property of the armed forces. In cases where a member of the armed forces commits a normal (civilian) criminal offense, the provincial or municipal court with appropriate jurisdiction should prosecute the alleged offender.32 [/expand] 1. Constitution of the Kingdom of Cambodia, article 150 2. Constitution of the Kingdom of Cambodia, article 151 3. Constitution of the Kingdom of Cambodia, articles 86, 152 and 153 4. រដ្ឋធម្មនុញ្ញ

រដ្ឋធម្មនុញ្ញ​ប្រទេស​កម្ពុជា​ដែល​ត្រូវ​បានអនុម័ត​ដោយ​ស្ថាប័ន​នីតិបញ្ញត្តិ​ត្រូវបាន​ប្រកាស​ឲ្យ​ប្រើ​នៅ​ថ្ងៃទី ២៤ ខែកញ្ញា ឆ្នាំ ១៩៩៣។ រដ្ឋធម្មនុញ្ញ​ជា​ច្បាប់កំពូល​នៃ​ព្រះរាជាណាចក្រ​កម្ពុជា ដែល​កំណត់​ស្ថាប័ន​និង រដ្ឋាភិបាល កម្ពុជា។ច្បាប់​និងសេចក្តីសម្រេច​ទាំងឡាយ​នៃ​ស្ថាប័ន​នានា​របស់​រដ្ឋ ត្រូវ​ស្រប​នឹង​រដ្ឋធម្មនុញ្ញ​ជាដាច់ខាត1។ រដ្ឋធម្មនុញ្ញ​គ្រប់គ្រង​បញ្ហា​អធិបតេយ្យភាព តួនាទី​និង​ឋានៈ​របស់​ព្រះមហាក្សត្រ សិទ្ធិ​ជា​មូលដ្ឋាន​របស់ ប្រជាពលរដ្ឋ​ខ្មែរ សេដ្ឋកិច្ច ការអប់រំ វប្បធម៌​និង​កិច្ចការ​សង្គម ការប្រព្រឹត្តទៅ​នៃ​រដ្ឋសភា ព្រឹទ្ធសភា សមាជ​និង​រាជរដ្ឋាភិបាល ការប្រព្រឹត្តទៅ​នៃ​ស្ថាប័ន​តុលាការ ក្រុមប្រឹក្សាធម្មនុញ្ញ រដ្ឋបាល​និង​សភា ជាតិ។ [expand title="សូមចុចនៅកន្លែងនេះដើម្បីទទួលបានពត៌មានលំអិតអំពីរដ្ឋធម្មនុញ្ញនិងក្រុមប្រឹក្សាធម្មនុញ្ញនៃប្រទេសកម្ពុជា។"] ការសើរើ​រដ្ឋធម្មនុញ្ញ ការផ្តើមគំនិត​សើរើ ឬ​ការផ្តើមគំនិត​ធ្វើ​វិសោធនកម្ម​រដ្ឋធម្មនុញ្ញ ជា​សិទ្ធិ​របស់​ព្រះមហាក្សត្រ របស់​នា យក​រដ្ឋមន្ត្រី និង​របស់​ប្រធានរដ្ឋសភា តាម​សេចក្តីស្នើ​របស់​តំណាងរាស្ត្រ​មួយ​ភាគ​បួន​នៃ​ចំនួន​សមា ជិ​ក​រដ្ឋសភា​ទាំងមូល2។ ការសើរើ​ឬ​វិសោធនកម្ម​រដ្ឋធម្មនុញ្ញ ត្រូវធ្វើឡើង​ដោយ​ច្បាប់រដ្ឋធម្មនុញ្ញ​មួយ ដែល​អនុម័ត​ដោយ​សភា តាម​មតិ​ភាគច្រើន​ពីរភាគបី​នៃ​ចំនួន​សមាជិក​រដ្ឋសភា​ទាំងមូល។ ការសើរើ​ឬ​វិសោធនកម្ម​រដ្ឋធម្មនុញ្ញ ត្រូវ​ហាមឃាត់​មិន​ឲ្យ​ធ្វើ​នៅពេល​ប្រទេសជាតិ​ស្ថិតក្នុង​ភាពអាសន្ន (សញ្ញាណ​មួយ​ដែល​មិនមាន​និយមន័យ​ច្បាប់​ច្បាស់លាស់) ឬ​ប្រសិនបើ​ការធ្វើ​វិសោធនកម្ម​នោះ​មាន ចេតនា​ធ្វើ​ឲ្យ​ប៉ះពាល់​ដល់​ប្រព័ន្ធ​លទ្ធិប្រជាធិបតេយ្យ សេរី​ពហុបក្ស ឬ​របបរាជានិយម​អាស្រ័យ​ដោយ​រដ្ឋ ធម្មនុញ្ញ។3 រដ្ឋធម្មនុញ្ញ​បាន​ត្រូវធ្វើ​វិសោធនកម្ម៥ដងៈ នៅ ឆ្នាំ១៩៩៤(ការផ្ទេរអំណាច​តាម​ការ​ឡាយ​ព្រះ​ហ​ស្ថ​របស់ ព្រះមហាក្សត្រ​ជូនទៅ​ប្រមុខរដ្ឋស្តីទី ឆ្នាំ១៩៩៩(ការបង្កើត​ស្ថាប័នព្រឹទ្ធសភា)ឆ្នាំ២០០១(ការបង្កើត​និង​ប្រទាន​ឥស្សរៈ​យស​មេដៃ​ដោយ​ព្រះមហាក្សត្រ)ឆ្នាំ២០០៥(ការធ្វើ​វិសោធនកម្ម​កូ​រ៉ូម​នៃ​អង្គប្រជុំ​និង​ការអនុម័ត​សម្លេង បោះឆ្នោត​របស់​រដ្ឋសភា​និង​ព្រឹទ្ធសភា និង​នៅ​ឆ្នាំ២០០៦(ការធ្វើ​វិសោធនកម្ម​កូ​រ៉ូម​នៃ​អង្គ ប្រជុំ​និង​ការអនុម័ត​សម្លេង​បោះឆ្នោត​របស់​រដ្ឋសភា​និង​ព្រឹទ្ធសភា4)។ ក្រុមប្រឹក្សាធម្មនុញ្ញ ក្រុមប្រឹក្សាធម្មនុញ្ញ មាន​សមាជិក៩រូប​ដែលមាន​អណ្ណ​ត្តិ៩ឆ្នាំៈ សមាជិក​ក្រុមប្រឹក្សាធម្មនុញ្ញ​ចំនួន មួយ​ភាគបី ត្រូវ​ផ្លាស់​ថ្មី​ក្នុង​រយៈពេល​បី​ឆ្នាំ​ម្តង បី​ឆ្នាំ​ម្តង។ សមាជិក​បី​រូប​ត្រូវ​តែងតាំង​ដោយ​ព្រះមហា ក្សត្រ បី​រូប​ត្រូវ​ជ្រើសតាំង​ដោយ​រដ្ឋសភា ហើយបី​រូប​ទៀត​ត្រូវ​តែងតាំង​ដោយ​ឧ​ត្ត​ម​ក្រុមប្រឹក្សា​នៃ​អង្គ ចៅក្រម។5 ក្រុមប្រឹក្សាធម្មនុញ្ញ​បំពេញបេសកកម្ម​ពី​រៈ (១)មាន​សមត្ថ​កិច្ចធានា​ការពារ​ការគោរព​រដ្ឋ​ធម្មនុញ្ញ​និង​បក ស្រាយ​រដ្ឋធម្មនុញ្ញ​និង​ច្បាប់​ដែល​សភា​បានអនុម័ត​និង​ព្រឹទ្ធសភា​បាន​ពិនិត្យ​ចប់សព្វគ្រប់​ហើយ និង(២) ក្រុមប្រឹក្សាធម្មនុញ្ញ​មាន​សិទ្ធិ​ពិនិត្យ​និង​សម្រេច​អំពី​ករណី​វិវាទកម្ម​ទាក់ទង​នឹង​ការបោះឆ្នោត​ជ្រើសរើស​សមាជិក​ព្រឹទ្ធសភា6។ ក្រុមប្រឹក្សាធម្មនុញ្ញ​មិនអាច​ផ្តួចផ្តើម​គំនិត​ធ្វើការ​សម្រេច​ទៅលើ​ធម្មនុញ្ញភាព​នៃ​ច្បាប់​បានទេ។ មានតែ ព្រះ មហាក្សត្រ ប្រធានព្រឹទ្ធសភា ប្រធានរដ្ឋសភា នាយករដ្ឋមន្ត្រី សម្លេងគាំទ្រ​មួយ​ភាគ​បួន​នៃ​សមា ជិ​ក​ព្រឹទ្ធសភា ឬ​តំណាងរាស្ត្រ​ចំនួន​មួយ​ភាគ​ដប់​ប៉ុណ្ណោះ អាច​បញ្ជូន​ច្បាប់​ដែល​រដ្ឋសភា​បានអនុម័ត និង​ពិនិត្យ​រួចរាល់​ដោយ​ព្រឹទ្ធសភា ទៅ​ក្រុមប្រឹក្សាធម្មនុញ្ញ​ដើ ម្បី​ពិនិត្យ មុន​ឬ​ក្រោយ​ការប្រកាស​ឲ្យ​ប្រើ7។ ការពិនិត្យ​ធម្មនុញ្ញភាព អាចធ្វើ​ទៅបាន​តាម​ការ​ទាមទារ​ពី ស្ថាប័ន​នីតិ​ប​ញ្ញ​តិ្ត នីតិប្រតិបត្តិ ឬ​ព្រះមហាក្សត្រ។ សមត្ថកិច្ច​របស់​ក្រុមប្រឹក្សា​ត្រូវ​កំណត់​ត្រឹម​ការពិនិត្យ​អំពី​ធម្មនុញ្ញភាព​នៃ​ច្បាប់​ប៉ុណ្ណោះ មានន័យថា​ក្រុមប្រឹក្សា​មិនត្រូវ​បានអនុញ្ញាត​ឲ្យ​គ្រប់គ្រង​ធម្មនុញ្ញភាព​នៃ​ទំ រង់​បទដ្ឋាន​ទាំងអស់​ដទៃទៀត​មានដូចជា (ក្រិ​ត្យ អនុ​ក្រិ​ត្យ……ជាដើម។ល) ពលរដ្ឋ​ដែលជា​ប់​ពាក់ព័ន្ធ​ក្នុង​រឿងក្តី​ណាមួយ​ហើយ​រឿងក្តី​នោះ​ឡើងដល់​តុលាការ ពលរដ្ឋ​នោះ​អាច លើក​អំពី​អធម្មនុញ្ញភាព​នូវ​បទបញ្ញត្តិ​ណាមួយ​នៃ​ច្បាប់ ឬ​សេចក្តីសម្រេច​របស់​ស្ថាប័ន​នានា​ដែល​គេ​អះ អាង​ថា​ប៉ះពាល់​ដល់​សិទ្ធិសេរីភាព​ជា​សារវន្ត​ណាមួយ​របស់គេ​ជូនទៅ​តុលាការ​បាន8។ បើ​យល់ឃើញថា ការលើកឡើង​នេះ​មាន​មូលដ្ឋាន​គ្រប់គ្រាន់ តុលាការ​ត្រូវ​លើក​ករណីនេះ​ទៅ​តុលាការ​កំពូល។ តុលា ការ​កំពូល​ត្រូវ​ចាត់ការ​ពិនិត្យ​និង​ប្តឹងទៅ​ក្រុមប្រឹក្សាធម្មនុញ្ញ។ ច្បាប់​មិនបាន​ណែនាំ​ឬ​ផ្តល់នូវ​លក្ខណៈ វិនិច្ឆ័យ​ណាមួយ​ថា​តើ​ស្ថាប័ន​ទាំងនេះ​ត្រូវ​កំណត់​ទទួល​ករណីនេះ​ឬ​យ៉ាងណា។ តាំងពី​មានការ​បង្កើត ឡើង​នៅ​ឆ្នាំ ១៩៩៨ ក្រុមប្រឹក្សាធម្មនុញ្ញ​បានទទួល​ពាក្យបណ្តឹង​តិចតួច​បំផុត​ហើយ​គ្មាន​ភាគី​ណាមួយ ដែល​ពាក់ព័ន្ធ​រឿងក្តី​ពេល​សវនាការ​មក​ដាក់ពាក្យ​បណ្តឹង​ឡើយ មានន័យថា​គ្មាន​បណ្តឹង​ចាត់​របៀប ណា​ធ្លាប់​បានមក​ដល់ដៃ​ក្រុមប្រឹក្សា​ទេ9។[/expand]

ឋានានុក្រម​នៃ​ច្បាប់​និង​បទបញ្ញត្តិ​នានា

ច្បាប់​និង​បញ្ញត្តិសំខាន់ៗទាំងឡាយ ត្រូវបាន​ចាត់ថ្នាក់​តាម​លំដាប់លំដោយ។ មាន​បទដ្ឋាន​ច្បាប់​ជា ច្រើន​បាន​ត្រូវអនុម័ត​ដោយ​អំណាច​នីតិ​ប​ញ្ញ​តិ្ត​និង​នីតិប្រតិបត្តិៈ ដូចជា រដ្ឋធម្មនុញ្ញ ច្បាប់ ក្រិ​ត្យ សេចក្តី​សំ​ម្រេច....។ល។ មាន​ឋានានុក្រម​ជាក់លាក់​រវាង​បទដ្ឋាន​ច្បាប់​ទាំងនេះ​ដូច្នេះ​គ្រប់​បទដ្ឋាន​និង​បទដ្ឋាននីមួយៗដែលមាន កំរិត​ថ្នាក់ទាប​ជាង​ត្រូវតែ​អនុលោម​តាម​បទដ្ឋាន​ច្បាប់​ណា​ដែលមាន​តម្លៃ​ខ្ពស់ជាង។ ទង្វើ​នេះ​ការពារ មិន​ឲ្យ​មានទំនាស់​រវាង​បទដ្ឋាន​និង​បទដ្ឋាន។ [expand title="សូមចុចនៅទីនេះដើម្បីរកមើលច្បាប់និងបញ្ញត្តិផ្សេងៗរបស់កម្ពុជា"]
  • រដ្ឋធម្មនុញ្ញ: ច្បាប់កំពូល​នៃ​ព្រះរាជាណាចក្រ​កម្ពុជា
  • សន្ធិសញ្ញា​អន្តរជាតិ: ព្រះមហាក្សត្រ​ឡាយ​ព្រះ​ហ​ស្ថ​និង​ធ្វើ​សច្ចាប័ន​លើ សន្ធិសញ្ញា​និង អនុសញ្ញា​អន្តរជាតិ​បន្ទាប់ពី​មានការ​អនុម័ត​ពី​រដ្ឋសភា​និង​ព្រឹទ្ធសភា។ បន្ទាប់ពី​ការធ្វើ​សច្ចាប័ន សន្ធិសញ្ញា​និង​អនុសញ្ញា​អន្តរជាតិ​ក្លាយជា​ច្បាប់​និង​អាច​ត្រូវបាន​ប្រើ​ជា​មូលដ្ឋាន​ក្នុង​ការធ្វើ​សេចក្តីសម្រេច​ដោយ​តុលាការ។ (មាត្រា ២៦នៃ​រដ្ឋធម្មនុញ្ញ)។
  • ច្បាប់ៈ ច្បាប់​អនុម័ត​ដោយ​រដ្ឋសភា។
  • ក្រម​និង​ក្រិ​ត្យ(ព្រះរាជក្រម​និង​ព្រះរាជ​ក្រិ​ត្យ): ក្រិ​ត្យ​ត្រូវ​បានចេញ​ក្រោម​ព្រះនាម​របស់​ព្រះ មហាក្សត្រ​ក្នុងការ​អនុវត្តន៍​អំណាច​រដ្ឋធម្មនុញ្ញ។
  • អនុ​ក្រិ​ត្យៈ ត្រូវបាន​ចុះហត្ថលេខា​ដោយ​នាយករដ្ឋមន្ត្រី​បន្ទាប់ពី​មានការ​អនុម័ត​ពី​កិច្ចប្រជុំ​ខុ​ទ្ទ កាល័យ។ ក្នុងករណី​ដែល​កិច្ចប្រជុំ​ខុទ្ទកាល័យ​មិនទាន់បាន​អនុម័ត​អនុ​ក្រិ​ត្យ ហត្ថលេខា​អម ដោយ​រដ្ឋមន្ត្រី​ទទួលបន្ទុក​ត្រូវតម្រូវ​ឲ្យ​មាន។ នាយករដ្ឋមន្ត្រី​អាច​ប្រើ​ហត្ថលេខា​នេះ​នៅក្នុង​ការអនុវត្ត​អំណាច​បញ្ញត្តិ​ផ្ទាល់​របស់ខ្លួន។
  • ប្រកាស: ត្រូវ​បានចេញ​ដោយ​សមាជិក​រដ្ឋាភិបាល​ក្នុងការ​អនុវត្តន៍​អំណាច​បញ្ញត្តិ​ផ្ទាល់​របស់ ខ្លួន។
  • សេចក្តីសម្រេច: សេចក្តីសម្រេច​រប​ស់បុ​គ្គល​ដែល​ធ្វើឡើង​ដោយ​នាយករដ្ឋមន្ត្រី រដ្ឋមន្ត្រី​ឬ​អ ភិ​បាល (ប្រកាសដីកា) ដែល​ត្រូវបានធ្វើ​នៅក្នុង​ការអនុវត្តន៍​អំណាច​បញ្ញត្តិ​ផ្ទាល់​របស់ខ្លួន។
  • សារាច​រៈ ជាទូទៅ សារាចរ​គឺ​ត្រូវ​បានចេញ​ដោយ​នាយករដ្ឋមន្ត្រី​ជា​ប្រមុខ​រដ្ឋាភិបាល និង​ដោយ រដ្ឋមន្ត្រី​ម្នាក់​ជា​មន្ត្រី​របស់​ក្រសួង​ពាក់ព័ន្ធ​ដែល​អាច​ពន្យល់​ប្រាប់​ឬ​ប្រកាស​វិធានការណ៍​និ​យ​ត កម្ម​ច្បាប់ ឬ​ផ្តល់នូវ​ការណែនាំ។
  • ដីកា​ខេត្តៈ ដីកា​ត្រូវ​បានចេញ​ដោយ​អភិបាលខេត្ត​នៅក្នុង​រង្វង់​ដែន​សមត្ថកិច្ច​ខេត្ត​របស់ខ្លួន។

ទោះបី​ជាមាន​ឋានានុក្រម​យ៉ាងនេះ​ក្តី ច្បាប់​និង​និយតកម្ម ជារឿយៗមានការ​ផ្ទុយគ្នា​ទៅវិញទៅមក។ ដោយសារតែ​គ្មាន​អំណាច​ឬ​អង្គភាព​ទទួលបន្ទុក​ណា​ត្រួតពិនិត្យ ឬ​សើរើ​ច្បាប់​និង​បញ្ញត្តិ​ដែល​មិន​ស្រប គ្នា​ឡើងវិញ។ ការភាន់ច្រឡំជារឿយៗកើតមាន​ថា​តើ​ច្បាប់​ឬ​បញ្ញត្តិ​មួយណា​គួរ​ត្រូវ​អនុវត្តតាម។[/expand]

ដំណើរការ​ស្ថាប័ន​នីតិបញ្ញត្តិ

រដ្ឋសភា​និង​ព្រឹទ្ធសភា​មានអំណាច​និតិ​បញ្ញត្តិ10។ សមាជិក​ព្រឹទ្ធសភា សមាជិក​រដ្ឋសភា​និង​នាយក​រដ្ឋ មន្ត្រី​មាន​សិទ្ធិ​ផ្តួច​ផ្តើមគំនិត​ធ្វើ​សេចក្តីព្រាងច្បាប់ ឬ​ស្នើ​ធ្វើ​វិសោធនកម្ម​ច្បាប់11។ ដំណើរការ​ច្បាប់​នេះ ជាធម្មតា​ប្រើ​រយៈពេល២ទៅ៣ខែ​ដើម្បី​បញ្ចប់។ យ៉ាងណាក្តី ក្នុងករណី​មាន​អាសន្ន ដំណើរការ​នេះ​ត្រូវ បាន​បំ​ព្រួញ​ហើយ​ច្បាប់​អាច​ត្រូវបាន​អនុម័ត​ក្នុង​រយៈពេល​ប៉ុន្មាន​ថ្ងៃ​ប៉ុណ្ណោះ។ ច្បាប់​ត្រូវ​បានអនុម័ត​បន្ទាប់ពី​មាន​សម្លេងគាំទ្រ​ភាគច្រើន​ដាច់ខាត (50% + 1)នៃ​រដ្ឋសភា បាន​បោះឆ្នោត​អនុម័ត​ច្បាប់​នោះ12។ [expand title="សូមចុចនៅកន្លែងនេះដើម្បីទទួលបានពត៌មានលំអិតអំពីដំណើរការច្បាប់នៅប្រទេសកម្ពុជា"]
  • អត្ថបទ​ភាគច្រើន​ដែល​ត្រូវបាន​បង្កើត​ចេញ​ជា​ទម្រង់ នឹង​ក្លាយជា​ពង្រាងច្បាប់ (ការផ្តួចផ្តើម​គំនិតរ​បស់​រដ្ឋា​ភិ បាល)។នៅពេលដែល​សេចក្តីព្រាងច្បាប់/សេចក្តីស្នើច្បាប់​ជា​គំនិត​ផ្តួចផ្តើម​របស់​ព្រឹទ្ធសភា តំណាង រាស្ត្រ​មាន​សិទ្ធិ​ស្នើ​ធ្វើ​វិសោធនកម្ម​ច្បាប់​ប៉ុន្តែ​សំណើរ​នេះ​មិនអាច​ទទួលយក​បានទេ​បើ​វិសោធនកម្ម​ច្បាប់​នោះ​សំដៅ​បន្ថយ​ប្រាក់ចំណូល​សាធារណៈ​ឬ​បន្ថែម​បន្ទុក​លើ​ប្រជាពលរដ្ឋ13។
  • ចំនួន​ច្បាប់​ដ៏​ច្រើន​ក្រាស់ក្រែល​ត្រូវបាន​ធ្វើឡើង​តាម​នីតិវិធី​យ៉ាង​ឆាប់រហ័ស​ដោយ​ផ្អែកលើ​ការប្រកាស​ស្ថានភាព​អាសន្ន មានន័យថា​ច្បាប់​ត្រូវបាន​អនុម័ត​ក្នុង​រយៈពេល​ពីរ​បី​ថ្ងៃ​និង​ទុកពេល តិចតួច​សម្រាប់​ការពិចារណា ឬ​ការធ្វើ​ឲ្យ​ច្បាប់​នោះ​ល្អឥតខ្ចោះ។ ឧទាហរណ៍​ច្បាប់​ស្តីពី​ស្ថាន ទម្ងន់ទោស​នៃ​បទល្មើស ឆ្នាំ (២០០២) ច្បាប់​ស្តីពី​រយៈពេល​នៃ​ការឃុំខ្លួន​បណ្តោះអាសន្ន ឆ្នាំ (១៩៩៩) ច្បាប់​ស្តីពី​ការរៀបចំ​និង​ការប្រព្រឹត្តទៅ​នៃ​ក្រុមប្រឹក្សាធម្មនុញ្ញ ឆ្នាំ (១៩៩៨)និង​ច្បាប់ ការងារ​ឆ្នាំ (១៩៩៧)ត្រូវបាន​អនុម័ត​តាម​ស្ថានភាព​ដំណើរការ​អនុម័ត​ច្បាប់​បន្ទាន់។
  • បើ​ព្រឹទ្ធសភា​សុំ​ឲ្យ​កែសម្រួល​សេចក្តីព្រាងច្បាប់ ឬ​សេចក្តីស្នើច្បាប់​នោះ រដ្ឋសភា​ត្រូវ​ពិនិត្យ​និង សម្រេច​តែ​ត្រង់​បទបញ្ញត្តិ​ឬ​ចំណុច​ណា​ដែល​ព្រឹទ្ធសភា​សុំ​ឲ្យ​កែសម្រួល​ដោយ​បដិសេធចោល ទាំងមូល ឬ​ទុកជាបានការ​ខ្លះ14។
  • ការ​បង្វិល​ទៅ​បង្វិល​មករ​វាង​ព្រឹទ្ធសភា​និង​រដ្ឋសភា​ត្រូវធ្វើ​ក្នុង​រយៈពេល​មួយខែ។ រយៈពេល​នេះ ត្រូវ​បន្ថយ​មក​ត្រឹម១០ថ្ងៃ បើ​ពិនិត្យ​ពី​ថវិការ​ជាតិ​និង​ហិរញ្ញវត្ថុ​ហើយ​មក​ត្រឹមតែ២ថ្ងៃ​បើជា​ការ​ប្រ ញាប់15។
  • បើ​ព្រឹទ្ធសភា​បដិសេធ​សេចក្តីព្រាងច្បាប់ ឬ​សេចក្តីស្នើច្បាប់​នោះ​ជា​អសារ​បង់ រដ្ឋសភា​មិនអាច នឹង​យកមក​ពិចារណា​ជា​លើក​ទី​ពីរបាន​មុន​រយៈពេល​មួយខែ​ទេ។ រយៈពេល​នេះ ត្រូវ​បន្ថយ​មក ត្រឹម១៥ថ្ងៃ​បើ​ពិនិត្យ​ពី​ថវិការ​ជាតិ​និង​ហិរញ្ញវត្ថុ​ហើយ​មក​ត្រឹមតែ៤ថ្ងៃ​បើជា​ការប្រញាប់16។
  • ច្បាប់​ដែល​រដ្ឋសភា​បានអនុម័ត​និង​ព្រឹទ្ធសភា​បាន​ពិនិត្យ​ចប់សព្វគ្រប់​រួចហើយ ត្រូវបាន​ព្រះ មហាក្សត្រ​ទ្រង់​បាន​ឡាយព្រះហស្ថលេខា​ប្រកាស​ឲ្យ​ប្រើ។
  • ច្បាប់​ត្រូវ​ចូល​ជាធរ​មាននៅ​រាជធានី​ភ្នំពេញ​ក្នុង​រយៈពេល១០ថ្ងៃ​គត់​ក្រោយ​ពីថ្ងៃ​ប្រកាស​ឲ្យ​ប្រើ និង​នៅ​ទូទាំងប្រទេស​ក្នុង​រយៈពេល២០ថ្ងៃ​គត់​ក្រោយ​ពីថ្ងៃ​ប្រកាស​ឲ្យ​ប្រើ។ ប៉ុន្តែ​បើ​ច្បាប់​នេះ បាន​ចែងថា “ជាការ​ប្រញាប់” ច្បាប់​នេះ​ត្រូវ​ចូល​ជា​ធរមាន​ភ្លាម​នៅ​ទូទាំងប្រទេស​ក្រោយ​ថ្ងៃ ប្រកាស​ឲ្យ​ប្រើ17។
  • ច្បាប់​ដែល​ព្រះមហាក្សត្រ​ទ្រង់​បាន​ឡាយព្រះហស្ថលេខា​ប្រកាស​ឲ្យ​ប្រើ ត្រូវ​ចុះ​ក្នុង​រាជកិច្ច​និង ផ្សព្វផ្សាយ​នៅ​ទូទាំងប្រទេស​ឲ្យ​ទាន់​តាម​ពេល​កំណត់​ខាងលើ18។[/expand]

ប្រព័ន្ធយុត្តិធម៌​និង​តុលាកា​រ

ប្រព័ន្ធយុត្តិធម៌​កម្ពុជា​រួមមាន​តុលាការ​សាលាដំបូង សាលាឧទ្ធរណ៍​និង​តុលាការ​កំពូល។យោងតាម​មាត្រា ១២៨ នៃ​រដ្ឋធម្មនុញ្ញ ប្រព័ន្ធយុត្តិធម៌​ត្រូវតែ “ឯករាជ្យ”ធានា​និង​ប្រកាន់ខ្ជាប់​អ​នាគ​តិ និង​ការពារ​សិទ្ធិ​និង​សេរីភាព​របស់​ពលរដ្ឋ។ រដ្ឋធម្មនុញ្ញ​ក៏បាន​ចែង​ផងដែរ​ថា​អំណាច​របស់​តុលាការ មិនអាច​ប្រគល់​ឲ្យ​ស្ថាប័ន​នីតិ​ប​ញ្ញ​តិ្ត​និង​នីតិប្រតិបត្តិ​បានទេ និង​ត្រូវ​គ្របដណ្តប់​លើ​បណ្តឹង​ទាំងអស់​រួម មាន​បណ្តឹង​រដ្ឋបាល​ផង។ រដ្ឋធម្មនុញ្ញ​នៃ​ប្រទេស​កម្ពុជា ទុក​តួនាទី​ឲ្យ​តុលាការ​ធ្វើការ​កំណត់​ក្នុង​ច្បាប់ ដោយឡែក។ ច្បាប់​ស្តីពី​ការចាត់តាំង និង​សកម្មភាព​របស់​សាលាជំរះក្តី​ត្រូវបាន​ប្រកាស​ឲ្យ​ប្រើ​នៅ ឆ្នាំ១៩៩៣។

ការ​ជំ​រះ​ផ្តល់​យុត្តិធម៌ ត្រូវធ្វើ​ក្នុងនាម​ប្រជារាស្ត្រ​ខ្មែរ តាម​នីតិវិធី​និង​ច្បាប់​ជា​ធរមាន។ មានតែ​ចៅក្រម​ទេ ដែលមាន​សិទ្ធិ​ជំ​រះ​ក្តី។ ចៅក្រម​ត្រូវបំពេញ​ភារកិច្ច​នេះ ដោយ​គោរព​ច្បាប់​យ៉ាង​ម៉ឺងម៉ាត់ និង​ឲ្យ​អស់ពី ដួងចិត្ត​និង​សម្បជញ្ញៈ​របស់ខ្លួន។ សិទ្ធិ​ទទួលបាន​សវនាការ​ត្រឹមត្រូវ​និង​យុត្តិធម៌​បាន​បង្កប់​នៅក្នុង​ច្បាប់​និង​វិធាន​នីតិវិធី​ដ៏​ធំធេង។ សច្ច​ធារ​ណ័​និរទោស បន្ទុក​បង្ហាញ​ភស្តុតាង​និង​វិធាន​គ្រប់គ្រង​ការទទួលយក​និង​ច្រានចោល​ភស្តុតាង គឺជា​ឧទាហរណ៍​នៃ​សិទ្ធិ​ប្រមូលផ្តុំ​ទាក់ទង​នឹង​សវនាការ​ត្រឹមត្រូវ​និង​យុត្តិធម៌​ដែលគ្រប់ៗគ្នា​ត្រូវ​ទទួល បាន។ [expand title="សូមចុចនៅកន្លែងនេះដើម្បីទទួលបានពត៌មានលំអិតថែមទៀតអំពីប្រព័ន្ធយុត្តិធម៌​និងតុលាការកម្ពុជា"] តុលាការ តុលាការខេត្ត​និង​ក្រុង តុលាការខេត្ត​និង​ក្រុង មាន​ទីតាំង​នៅក្នុង​ខេត្ត​និង​ក្នុង​ក្រុង។ តុលាការខេត្ត ក្រុង​ដែល​ត្រូវ​តាំងនៅ​ខេត្ត ក្រុងមាន​សមត្ថកិច្ច​គ្រ​ប​ដណ្តប់​លើ​ដែនដី​នៃ​ខេត្ត ក្រុង​ទាំងនោះ ក្នុងការ​ជំ​រះ​ក្តី​លើ​ករណី​វិវាទ​ការងារ រដ្ឋបាល ពាណិជ្ជកម្ម ព្រហ្មទណ្ឌ​និង​រដ្ឋប្បវេណី20។ ជាគោលការណ៍ តុលាការខេត្ត ក្រុង​ត្រូវបាន​បែង ចែកជា​ពីរ​ស្ថា​ប័នៈ គឺ​ស្ថាប័ន​រដ្ឋប្បវេណី​និង​ស្ថាប័ន​អយ្យការ(ព្រហ្មទណ្ឌ)។ទោះជា​យ៉ាងនេះ​ក្តី ជា​ទម្លាប់ ក្នុងការ​អនុវត្តន៍ និង​ដោយសារ​ចំនួន​ចៅក្រម​មានកំណត់ ដូច្នេះ​មិនមាន​ការបែងចែក​ច្បាស់លាស់​រវាងស្ថាប័ន​ទាំងនេះ​ទេ។ ចៅក្រមជារឿយៗកាន់​សំណុំ​រឿងក្តី​ទាំង​ព្រហ្មទណ្ឌ​និង​ស៊ី​វី​ល21។ ព្រះរាជអាជ្ញា​សាធារណៈ​អម​តុលាការនីមួយៗ22។ មានតែ​ស្ថាប័ន​អយ្យការ​សាធារណៈ​ប៉ុណ្ណោះ​ដែល មាន​សិទ្ធិ​ធ្វើ​បណ្តឹងអាជ្ញា23។ តុលាការខេត្ត ក្រុង​ជំនុំ​ជំ​រះ​ក្តី​មាន​ចៅក្រម​ម្នាក់ និង​ត្រូវបំពេញ​ដោយ​រដ្ឋ​អា ជ្ញា ឬ​រដ្ឋអាជ្ញារង​ម្នាក់ និង​ក្រឡាបញ្ជី​ម្នាក់24។ សាលក្រម​សម្រេចសេចក្តី​ចំពោះមុខ​របស់​តុលាការខេត្ត ក្រុង​បើក​ឲ្យ​ប្តឹង​ឧទ្ធរណ៍​ក្នុង​រយៈពេល២ខែ គិតពី​ថ្ងៃ​កាត់សេចក្តី។ សាលក្រម​កំបាំងមុខ​បើក​ឲ្យ​ប្តឹង​ជំទាស់​ក្នុង​រយៈពេល ១៥ថ្ងៃ គិតពី​ថ្ងៃ​ទទួលដំណឹង។ បើ​ផុតកំណត់ ប្តឹង​ជំទាស់ អាច​ប្តឹង​ឧទ្ធរណ៍​បាន​ក្នុង​រយៈពេល​ពីរ​ខែ គិតពី​ថ្ងៃ​ផុតកំណត់​ប្តឹង​ជំទាស់។25 សាលាឧទ្ធរណ៍ សាលាឧទ្ធរណ៍​ដែលជា​តុលា​ការជាន់​ខ្ពស់ជាង​តុលាការខេត្ត ក្រុងមាន​ទីតាំងនៅ​ក្រុងភ្នំពេញ។ សាលា ឧទ្ធរណ៍​មាន​សមត្ថកិច្ច​គ្របដណ្តប់​លើ​ដែនដី​នៃ​ព្រះរាជាណាចក្រ​កម្ពុជា​ទាំងមូល26។ ការប្តឹងតវ៉ា​ទៅ​សាលាឧទ្ធរណ៍​មិនមាន​ល័ក្ខខ័ណ្ឌ​ចងភ្ជាប់​ជាមួយ​មក​ទេ ដោយសារតែ​គ្មាន ច្បាប់​ឬ​គោលការណ៍​ណែនាំ​បញ្ជាក់​អំពី​ហេតុផល​ដែល​តម្រូវ​ឲ្យ​ធ្វើ​បណ្តឹងឧទ្ធរណ៍។ មិនមាន​យន្តការ ណាមួយ​ដើម្បី​ច្រោះ​យកចេញ​បណ្តឹងឧទ្ធរណ៍​ណា​ដែល​មិន​សម​ហេតុផល ឬ​គ្មាន​មូលហេតុ​ច្បាស់ លាស់​ទេ។ គ្មាន​ការដាក់ទោស​ចំពោះ​ការធ្វើ​បណ្តឹងឧទ្ធរណ៍​ណា​ដែល​មិនមាន​ហេតុផល​ពិតប្រាកដ ឬ មិន​សម​ហេតុ​សម ផល​នោះឡើយ។ តុលាការ​កំពូល តុលាការ​កំពូល ដែលមាន​ទីតាំងនៅ​ក្រុងភ្នំពេញ គឺជា​តុលាការ​ជាន់ខ្ពស់​បំផុត​នៅ​ប្រទេស​កម្ពុជា​និង​ជា សាលាជំរះក្តី​ចុងក្រោយ​គេ​បង្អស់។ តុលាការ​នេះ មាន​ចៅក្រម ១២ រូប​និង​ព្រះរាជអាជ្ញា​បួនរូប។ តុលាការ​កំពូល​មាន​សមត្ថកិច្ច​បន្ត​បើកសវនាការ​លើ​បណ្តឹង​សារទុក្ខ​ជំទាស់​នឹង​សាលដីកា​របស់​សាលាឧទ្ធរណ៍​ដោយ​ពិចារណា​តែ​លើ​អង្គច្បាប់​ប៉ុណ្ណោះ។ តុលាការ​កំពូល​មិនអាច​ពិចារណា​ទៅលើ​អង្គហេតុ ទេ។ ឧ​ត្ត​ម​ក្រុមប្រឹក្សា​នៃ​អង្គចៅក្រម មាត្រា ១៣២ទៅ ១៣៤នៃ​រដ្ឋធម្មនុញ្ញ​បង្កើត​ឧ​ត្ត​ម​ក្រុមប្រឹក្សា​នៃ​អង្គចៅក្រម ដើម្បី​ធានា​ឯករាជ្យភាព និង​ភាពល្អប្រសើរ​នៃ​ប្រព័ន្ធយុត្តិធម៌។ ឧ​ត្ត​ម​ក្រុមប្រឹក្សា​នៃ​អង្គចៅក្រម​មាន​សមាជិក ៩រូប​ដូចតទៅៈ ព្រះមហាក្សត្រ​ដែល​ធ្វើជា​ប្រធាន រដ្ឋមន្ត្រី​ក្រសួងយុត្តិធម៌ ប្រធាន​តុលាការ​កំពូល អគ្គព្រះរាជអាជ្ញា អម​តុលាការ​កំពូល ប្រធាន​សាលាឧទ្ធរណ៍ ព្រះរាជអាជ្ញា​សាលាឧទ្ធរណ៍​និង​ចៅក្រម៣រូប27។ ឧ​ត្ត​ម​ក្រុមប្រឹក្សា​នៃ​អង្គចៅក្រម​និង​រដ្ឋមន្ត្រី​ក្រសួងយុត្តិធម៌​មាន​ឥ​ទិ្ធ​ពល​ចំបង​មួយ​ទៅលើ​ចៅក្រម​ទាំង អស់​នៅ​តុលាការ​គ្រប់​ជាន់ថ្នាក់ៈ អំណាច​របស់គេ​ដែល​តែងតាំង ដាក់វិន័យ​និង​ណែនាំ​មន្ត្រី​យុត្តិធម៌ ទាំងអស់28 សម្រេច​ដាក់វិន័យ​លើ​ចៅក្រម​និង​ព្រះរាជអាជ្ញា​ណា​ដែល​បាន​ប្រព្រឹត្ត​ខុស29។ ឧ​ត្ត​ម​ក្រុម ប្រឹក្សា​នៃ​អង្គចៅក្រម​ត្រូវបាន​គេ​រិះគន់​ចំពោះ​ការខកខាន​មិនបាន​បំពេញ​អណ្ណ​ត្តិ​របស់ខ្លួន​ដោយ​ផ្អែក តាម​ការចោទប្រកាន់ថា​បាន​ប្រព្រឹត្ត​អំពើពុករលួយ ខ្វះ​ស្វ័យភាព​និង​មាន​និន្នាការ​នយោបាយ30។ តុលាការយោធា តុលាការយោធា​ស្ថិតនៅ​ក្រៅពី​ប្រព័ន្ធតុលាការ​ធម្មតា។ ដោយបាន​បង្កើតឡើង​នៅ​ឆ្នាំ ១៩៨១និង​មាន ទីតាំងនៅ​ទីក្រុង​ភ្នំពេញ តុលាការ​នេះ​ជំនុំ​ជំ​រះ​ករណី​ណា​ដែល​ទាក់ទង​នឹង​បទល្មើស​យោធា31។ នីតិវិធី របស់​តុលាការយោធា​ដូចគ្នា​នឹង​នីតិវិធី​របស់​តុលាការខេត្ត ក្រុង បទល្មើស​យោធា គឺជា​បទល្មើស​ដែល​ត្រូវបាន​ប្រព្រឹត្តឡើង​ដោយ​សមាជិក​យោធា (យោធិន)នៅក្នុងកងកម្លាំងប្រដាប់អាវុធ​ហើយ​បទល្មើស​ទាំងនោះ​ពាក់ព័ន្ធ​នឹង​វិន័យ​យោធា​ឬ​ទ្រព្យសម្បត្តិ​របស់​កងទ័ព។ ក្នុងករណី​ដែល​សមាជិក​នៃ​កងកម្លាំងប្រដាប់អាវុធ​ណា​ប្រព្រឹត្ត​បទល្មើស​ព្រហ្មទណ្ឌ   20. ច្បាប់​​​​​​​ស្តីពី​​​​​​​ការចាត់តាំង​​​​​​​និង​​​​​​​សកម្មភាព​​​​​​​របស់​​​​​​​សាលាជំរះក្តី ថ្ងៃទី៨ ខែ​​​​​​​គុ​​​​​​​ម្ភៈ ឆ្នាំ ១៩៩៣​ មាត្រា ២
  21. សៀវភៅ​​​​​​​របស់លោក​​​​​​​កុយ នាម ដែលមាន​​​​​​​ចំណងជើង​​​​​​​ថា​​​​​​​៉​​​​​​​ការណែនាំ​​​​​​​អំពី​​​​​​​នីតិវិធីតុលាការ​​​​​​​កម្ពុជា​​​​​​​៉ នៅ​​​​​​​អង្គការ មូល​​​​​​​នី​​​​​​​ធិ​​​​​​​អាស៊ី​​​​​​​ឆ្នាំ១៩៩៨
  22. ច្បាប់​​​​​​​ស្តីពី​​​​​​​ការចាត់តាំង​​​​​​​និង​​​​​​​សកម្មភាព​​​​​​​របស់​​​​​​​សាលាជំរះក្តី ថ្ងៃទី៨ ខែ​​​​​​​គុ​​​​​​​ម្ភៈ ឆ្នាំ ១៩៩៣​ មាត្រា ៥​ វាក្យ​​​​​​​ខ័​​​​​​​ណ្ឌ ។
  23. រដ្ឋធម្មនុញ្ញ​​​​​​​នៃ​​​​​​​ព្រះរាជាណាចក្រ​​​​​​​កម្ពុជា មាត្រា ។
  24. ច្បាប់​​​​​​​ស្តីពី​​​​​​​ការចាត់តាំង​​​​​​​និង​​​​​​​សកម្មភាព​​​​​​​របស់​​​​​​​សាលាជំរះក្តី ថ្ងៃទី៨ ខែ​​​​​​​គុ​​​​​​​ម្ភៈ ឆ្នាំ ១៩៩៣​ មាត្រា ៦ ។
  25. ច្បាប់​​​​​​​ស្តីពី​​​​​​​ការចាត់តាំង​​​​​​​និង​​​​​​​សកម្មភាព​​​​​​​របស់​​​​​​​សាលាជំរះក្តី ថ្ងៃទី៨ ខែ​​​​​​​គុ​​​​​​​ម្ភៈ ឆ្នាំ ១៩៩៣​ មាត្រា ។
  26. ច្បាប់​​​​​​​ស្តីពី​​​​​​​ការចាត់តាំង​​​​​​​និង​​​​​​​សកម្មភាព​​​​​​​របស់​​​​​​​សាលាជំរះក្តី ថ្ងៃទី៨ ខែ​​​​​​​គុ​​​​​​​ម្ភៈ ឆ្នាំ ១៩៩៣​ មាត្រា ៣ ។
  27. S. Sok and D. Sarin ប្រព័ន្ធ​​​​​​​ច្បាប់​​​​​​​កម្ពុជា មជ្ឈមណ្ឌល​​​​​​​អភិវឌ្ឍន៍​​​​​​​ធនធាន​​​​​​​ច្បាប់​​​​​​​កម្ពុជា ឆ្នាំ ១៩៩៨ ទំព័រ ៥៤ ដល់។
  28. រដ្ឋធម្មនុញ្ញ​​​​​​​នៃ​​​​​​​ព្រះរាជាណាចក្រ​​​​​​​កម្ពុជា មាត្រា ។
  29. របាយការណ៍​​​​​​​របស់​​​​​​​អង្គការសហប្រជាជាតិៈ​​​​​​​ព្រះរាជាណាចក្រ​​​​​​​កម្ពុជាៈ ទម្រង់​​​​​​​បែបបទ​​​​​​​រដ្ឋបាល​​​​​​​សាធារណៈ របស់​​​​​​​ប្រទេស​​​​​​​ភ្នំពេញ២០០៤ ទំព័រ ។
  30. ការិយាល័យ​​​​​​​នៃ​​​​​​​ឧ​​​​​​​ត្ត​​​​​​​ម​​​​​​​ស្នងការ​​​​​​​សិទ្ធិមនុស្ស​​​​​​​របស់​​​​​​​អង្គការសហប្រជាជាតិ​​​​​​​ដែលមាន​​​​​​​ទីស្នាក់ការ​​​​​​​នៅ​​​​​​​ប្រទេស​​​​​​​កម្ពុជា​​​​​​​៉​​​​​​​កត់​​​​​​​សំ​គាល់ លើ​​​​​​​ការកែទម្រង់​​​​​​​ប្រព័ន្ធយុត្តិធម៌​​​​​​​និង​​​​​​​ច្បាប់​​​​​​​សម្រាប់​​​​​​​ក្រុម​​​​​​​ពិគ្រោះ​​​​​​​យោបល់​​​​​​​ពាក់កណ្តាល​​​​​​​អណ្ណ​​​​​​​ត្តិ​​​​​​​នៅ​​​​​​​កិច្ចប្រជុំ​​​​​​​ម្ចាស់ជំនួយ ៉​​​​​​​ភ្នំពេញ ឆ្នាំ ២០០៣ ទំព័រ ។
  31. ច្បាប់​​​​​​​ស្តីពី​​​​​​​ការចាត់តាំង​​​​​​​និង​​​​​​​សកម្មភាព​​​​​​​របស់​​​​​​​សាលាជំរះក្តី ថ្ងៃទី៨ ខែ​​​​​​​គុ​​​​​​​ម្ភៈ ឆ្នាំ ១៩៩៣​ មាត្រា ២ ។៣២ ច្បាប់​​​​​​​ស្តីពី​​​​​​​ការចាត់តាំង​​​​​​​និង​​​​​​​សកម្មភាព​​​​​​​របស់​​​​​​​សាលាជំរះក្តី ថ្ងៃទី៨ ខែ​​​​​​​គុ​​​​​​​ម្ភៈ ឆ្នាំ ១៩៩៣​ មាត្រា ៩ ។

item.title: National Elections Briefing
item.dc:creator: odc_admin
item.content:encoded:
Cambodia held its fifth National Assembly election on July 28, 2013. Preliminary results released by the National Election Committee (NEC) show that over six and a half million Cambodians, or 68 per cents of all eligible voters, turned out to cast their ballots. Out of eight political parties competing in the election, two parties, the ruling Cambodian People’s Party (CPP) and the main opposition, the Cambodian National Rescue Party (CNRP), obtained the largest shares of votes. Although the NEC has yet to officially announce the number of seats obtained by political parties in the election, the CPP declared itself the winner, claiming it has obtained 68 seats in the National Assembly, as opposed to 55 obtained by the CNRP. The CNRP, however, rejected the preliminary results, citing massive irregularities. The party also declared election victory, saying it has received at least 63 seats in the National Assembly. This briefing provides an overview of elections in Cambodia, focusing on history of the national elections, legal framework, and actors and institutions involved.
Overview of Cambodia’s Government Structure
The Cambodian government is a constitutional monarchy in which the King does not have substantive political power. The King is selected by the Crown Council, a 9-member group including the Prime Minister, presidents and first and second vice-presidents of the National Assembly and the Senate, as well as the two Buddhist religious leaders, to serve for life as the Head of State while the elected Prime Minister heads up the government. Under Cambodia’s Constitution, the government functions as a parliamentary democracy with three branches of government: executive, legislative, and judicial. The Constitution also describes the composition of each of these groups. Executive Branch The Council of Ministers, also known as the Cabinet of Cambodia, is the head of the executive branch of government and is in charge of executing national policies. The Council of Ministers is led by the Prime Minister, who is chosen through a vote of confidence by the National Assembly from among the newly elected members of the winning party. Council members are nominated by the Prime Minister and formally appointed by the King. To be eligible for nomination, they must be members of the National Assembly or members of the parties represented at the National Assembly. The Council of Ministers has twenty-six ministries and two secretariats. The Council of Ministers is, by constitution, accountable to the National Assembly. Legislative Branch The legislature is responsible for making and passing laws. Laws passed by the legislature are given to the King to approve. The legislature is composed of a Parliament with two houses: the Senate and the National Assembly. The Senate has 61 members who serve six-year terms. Two members are appointed by the King, two members are elected by the National Assembly through a simple majority vote, and the remaining 57 members are elected by commune councilors and members of the National Assembly every six years. The National Assembly currently has 123 members who serve five-year terms. The National Assembly must have at least 120 members. However the exact number of Assembly seats varies based on changes to the population. The National Assembly is led by a President and two Vice Presidents selected by the National Assembly, through an absolute majority vote, prior to each legislative session. Each legislative session must last at least three months. Members of the National Assembly are elected through a closed-list proportional representative system, in which voters vote for political parties as a whole, rather than specific candidates. Parties then name candidates to the seats they have won. Judicial Branch Cambodia's judiciary comprises Municipal/Provincial Courts, a Military Court, an Appellate Court and a Supreme Court. These courts are under the supervision of the Supreme Council of Magistracy (SCM), a body which is responsible for appointing and disciplining judges and prosecutors and ensuring the proper functioning of the judiciary. The King chairs the SCM and also approves recommendations submitted by this body on the appointment, suspension and removal of judges. By constitution, the judiciary must be independent from both the executive and legislative branches.
History of National Elections Since 1993 1993: In 1993, the United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia (UNTAC) helped Cambodia prepare for its first post-war election. Over four million Cambodians, or more than 90% of all eligible voters, participated. Prince Norodom Ranariddh’s FUNCINPEC Party received the most votes. FUNCINPEC created a coalition government with all of the parties that participated in the election. In an agreement brokered by the then Prince Sihanouk, Prince Ranariddh and CPP’s Hun Sen were selected as First and Second Prime Ministers. This coalition government drafted a new Constitution that created a constitutional monarchy and multiparty liberal democracy. 1998: FUNCINPEC leaders, exiled the previous year after a brief civil conflict, were allowed to return to Cambodia in order to lead their party in the 1998 national election. The CPP received the most votes, followed by FUNCINPEC and the Sam Rainsy Party (SRP.) The CPP and FUNCINPEC formed a coalition government with the CPP as the dominant party. The dual-Prime Minister system was ended and CPP leader Hun Sen became the sole Prime Minister. 2003: Hun Sen’s CPP won a majority of the seats in the National Assembly, but did not win the two-thirds majority required to elect its own Prime Minister or form a government. There were then several months of negotiation with FUNCINPEC as the intended coalition partner. The impasse was broken by an “Additional Constitutional Law”, which was hastily drafted and adopted in July 2004. The law requires that the leaders of the National Assembly and Executive Branch be elected through a so-called “package vote”, rather than separate votes as required by the 1993 constitution. After this, CPP reached a deal with FUNCINPEC to form a coalition government and Hun Sen was named to another term as Prime Minister. 2008: Up until the 2003 national election, the constitution required a two-third majority in the National Assembly in order to form a government. This particular rule was amended in 2006 by the National Assembly to allow for a simple majority (50% plus one) in the Assembly to create a government. In the 2008 national election, the CPP won a record 58.11% of the votes, representing 90 out of the 123 National Assembly seats. The SRP won 21.91% of the vote and 26 seats. The newly formed Human Rights Party finished third, while FUNCINPEC finished fifth behind the Norodom Ranariddh Party, an offshoot that split from FUNCINPEC in 2006.

Seats Obtained by Political Parties

1993 National Election

1998 National Election

2003 National Election

2008 National Election

National Liberation Movement of Cambodia Party (Molinaka)
Funcinpec Party (FCP)
Cambodian People's Party (CPP)
Human Rights Party (HRP)
Buddhist Liberal Democratic Party (BLDP)
Norodom Ranaridh Party (NRP)
Sam Rainsy Party (SRP)
Frequently Asked Questions about the National Elections National elections in Cambodia are governed by the Law on the Election of the Members of National Assembly (LEMNA). When are National Elections Held? National elections are held every five years on a Sunday at a date determined by the Prime Minister. Who Administers the Elections? The National Election Committee (NEC) is the organization responsible for administering the elections. The NEC also has Provincial/Municipal Election Commissions (PECs), Commune/Sangkat Election Commissions (CECs), and Polling Station Commissions (PSCs) to support its work throughout the nation. Who May Vote? A voter must be a Cambodian national, be 18 years old or older on Election Day, and have residence in the commune/sangkat where he/she wants to cast his/her vote. Additionally, a voter can only be registered at one polling station. Any Cambodian citizen who has more than one residence in the Kingdom of Cambodia must choose which residence to use to register as a voter. Prisoners and the mentally ill are not permitted to vote. One challenge that some Cambodian voters, such as factory workers, face is that their identification is for a location other than their current residence, usually based on their first home. This means that they must travel a long distance, first, to register and then to vote. Can I Vote If I Am Currently Living Outside of Cambodia? At present, elections are only held within Cambodia’s territory, which means that even if otherwise eligible, Cambodian citizens cannot vote from abroad. How Do I Register to Vote? A citizen can only register within the period determined by the NEC. Normally, voter registration takes place once a year between October and December with the exact registration period varies from year to year depending on the NEC’s decision. In order to register to vote, you are required to present yourself at the commune/sangkat office during the registration period. You must show documentation to prove that you are a Cambodian citizen, 18 years old or older on Election Day, and have residence in the commune/sangkat where you plan to vote. Once I’m Registered, How Can I Ensure I am on the Voting List? You may verify that you are on the voter list only within the specific voter registration and verification period as determined by the NEC, at the place where you have registered to vote. If you cannot find your name on the voter list, you must immediately file a complaint to the relevant election agency. After the period of voter registration and verification has passed, complaints regarding registration are not generally accepted by the NEC. At present, voters can also search for their names o nline v ia NEC’s website. Where Do I Vote? You may only vote at the specific polling station where you are registered. The NEC establishes at least 1 polling station in each commune/sangkat, with no polling station serving more than 700 voters. By law, the names and locations of all polling stations will be made available to the public at least 30 days before the polling day at all polling stations. What Must I Bring With Me on the Election Day? You are required to bring legal documentation to prove your identity. Such documents may include a Cambodian passport, a national identification card, identification cards for military, police, and Buddhist monks, birth certificates, and letters of certification from local authorities. What If I Have Verified My Name Prior to Election, but When I Get to the Polling Station It is Not There? Although the election law does not clearly specify what a registered voter, who has verified his/her name on a list, should do when he or she cannot find his/her name at the polling station on election day, it does say that any person can file a complaint to relevant election agencies and the Constitutional Council regarding issues pertaining to the election. Who Can Compete in the Elections? Anyone who wants to be a candidate for the National Assembly must be a Cambodian national by birth, have a residence in the Kingdom of Cambodia, be eligible to vote, be at least twenty-five (25) years of age on the date of the election, and be nominated by a registered political party running in the election. Some people cannot compete as candidates, including actively serving civil servants, court officials, NEC officials, members of the armed forces and national police, and religious priests. Additionally, those who have been convicted of a crime but have not been rehabilitated by the criminal justice system may not vote. Which Parties Can Compete in the Elections? Any party that wants to compete in the elections must register with the NEC no later than 70 days before Election Day. The NEC must rule on the party’s eligibility within 7 days of receiving the application. The NEC must inform parties of any deficiencies in their application, after which they have 5 days to make corrections. A party that has had their application rejected by the NEC has a right to appeal the decision within 5 days of the decision. The Constitutional Council must then decide on the party’s appeal within 10 days of receiving the appeal. What are the Rules for Campaigning? The goal of the electoral campaign period is to allow political parties and candidates competing in the election to share their ideas with the voters in an open and peaceful manner. No political party or candidate may use threats, intimidation or violence against citizens, other political parties or candidates, or incite supporters to do so on their behalf. Penalties for any of these illegal activities include being barred from voting and competing in the elections as well as fines ranging from 5 million to 25 million riels. Political parties and candidates may rent public or private theaters, stadiums, public parks, and halls as long as they apply for permission to use these venues at least 3 days before their scheduled event. They must send also a copy of this application to the Commune/Sangkat Electoral Commission. The manager of the facility shall respond to the applicant within 24 hours after receiving the application. The use of government offices and vehicles for campaigning purpose is prohibited by law. Campaigning lasts 30 days and all activities of the electoral campaign must end 24 hours before the polling day. What are Rules for Access to Media Coverage? All media outlets, including state-run press, television and radio, must broadcast information at the request of the NEC at no cost, in order to publicize election-related activities and to educate voters. By law, he NEC will publicize participating political parties’ messages based on a “first-come, first-served” basis. What are Election Observation and Monitoring Groups? Election observation and monitoring groups are non-partisan organizations that observe, analyze, and report on election-related activities before, during, and after the actual election day. Here are some groups observing and monitoring elections in Cambodia. Committee on Free and Fair Elections in Cambodia (COMFREL): http://www.comfrel.org/eng/ National Democratic Institute (NDI): http://www.ndi.org/cambodia Neural and Impartial Committee for Free and Fair Elections in Cambodia (NICFEC): http:///www.nicfec.wordpress.com/ Asian Network for Free Elections (ANFREL; 2013 report likely to be released after election): http://anfrel.org/category/country-profiles/cambodia/ What are Election Observers? Individuals known as “observers” may monitor all election activities before, during, and after the election. There are several different types of observers. Political observers are agents from political parties running in the election and are responsible for representing the interests of their respective parties. Each political party running in the election may send two observers to each polling station. Foreign nations, non-governmental organizations, and international organizations may also send independent observers. Independent observers, are not affiliated with parties, and are responsible for objectively and impartially observing all general election activities. All observers must be approved by the NEC, and must carry an Observer Identification Card issued by the NEC during their missions. International observers may travel anywhere in Cambodia without needing prior permission. National observers must stay in the province/municipality in which they were approved to observe. What If I Have an Elections-Related Complaint? According to the election law, you may first file the complaint to the commune/sangkat election commission (SEC) where the irregularity happened. If you are not satisfied with SEC’s decision, you may file an appeal to the provincial election commission (PEC). If you still find PEC’s decision unsatisfactory, you may finally file an appeal to the National Election Committee. Alternatively, you may also file a complaint directly to the Constitutional Council. How Can I Learn More About Elections? There are several groups in Cambodia that have voter education programs. Here is a list of links to organizations providing voter education information online. National Election Committee (NEC): http://www.necelect.org.kh/nec_english/ BBC Loy9 (A tv and radio program designed to share information about civic participation including elections): http://www.bbc.co.uk/mediaaction/publicationsandpress/research_cambodia_loy9_page.html COMFREL: http://www.comfrel.org/eng/index.php?option=com_content&view=category&layout=blog&id=136&Itemid=1054 (This briefing was lasted updated on 7 August 2013.)

item.title: Job Announcements
item.dc:creator: odc_admin
item.content:encoded:
SPATIAL PLANNING LAB PROJECT

Term of Reference

Job title:Mapping Instructor (part-time) Reports to:ODC Research & Volunteer Coordinator, ODC Mapping Coordinator and Executive Director/ Editor-in-Chief Coordinates with:Spatial Planning Lab project partners, ODC staff Background/Context: Spatial planning and land management requires multidisciplinary expertise. Planners, in order to perform their tasks effectively and ensure that land is managed in sustainable manner must learn not only about administrative and legal frameworks, mapping and zoning. They also need to learn how to protect the people from natural and man- made disasters such as flooding, landslides, pollution, etc and ensure access to basic social services and livelihoods opportunities. In order to build peaceful and, resilient communities and nation, it is essential to put people and their rights at the heart of the spatial planning process. Far too often, spatial decisions contribute to exclusion of vulnerable and marginalized groups, favoring unsustainable but profitable land uses. The role of spatial planners is to identify win-win solutions for all stakeholders to ensure Cambodia’s economic development while not violating human rights of its citizens. Spatial Planning Lab is carried out over a 6-month period and includes 3 components: (1). Geographic Information System (GIS) Lab: One 3-hour session weekly and some field trips, to be conducted by ODC GIS Instructor. (2). Spatial Planning Lecture Series and Workshops: One 2 or 3-hour session bi-weekly, to be facilitated by PIN. (3). Research/Technical Consultation: One 30-minute session after each lecture or workshop in component 2, to be facilitated by PIN and/or ODC. The three components compliment each other and are designed to provide a holistic learning experience for the future land use planners and encourages them to draw connections between theory and practice. The GIS Lab emphasizes skill training and hands-on technical applications. The Spatial Planning Lecture Series and Workshops have been designed to raise awareness of the future land use planning in relation to spatial challenges such as Climate Change, Disaster Risk Reduction, Gender and Inclusive and Participatory Spatial Development respecting Royal Government of Cambodia planning framework.The Research/Technical Consultation sessions provide thesis-writing students with informal guidance and feedback on their spatial planning related research and technical analysis. Call for Applications Open Development Cambodia seeks a part-time mapping instructor (32hrs from November 1, 2014 to December 31, 2014) to teach the GIS Lab component of the Spatial Planning Lab. The purpose of this lab is to provide students practial applications in spatial planning excercises using  Geographic Information System, remote sensing principles, web mapping  technology, and open data from Cambodia. Primary Responsibilities Develops lesson plans and conducts the GIS Lab including, but not limited to, fieldworks conducted by the project partners. Ensure linkages between the Lecture Series component of the Spatial Planning Lab and
  • Develop a 32-hour curriculum according to students’s skills and needs.
  • Conduct GIS training; ensuing that the GIS Lab excercises corresponds to the Lecture Series, to be conducted by People in Need, and Open Development Cambodia’s projects, as requested by ODC Mapping Coordinator.
  • Research and/or confere with ODC Mapping Coordinator to identify relavant sectoral, demographic, environmental, economic, and geographic areas for mapping and spatial/graphical representation needed for the excercises.
  • Ensure that maps and other infographics meet ODC publishing standard and are supported with appropriate and complete metadata.
  • Oversee project fieldworks and test the ODC Mapping Kit with students as requested.
  • Document teaching materials and outputs to be shared with project partners.
  • Conduct two assessment tests with students; measure their perofrmance.
  • Produce a written report on the GIS Lab relecting the contractin periods.
  • Update the ODC Reserach & Volunteer Coordinator/ODC Mapping Coordinator on project developments via e-mail on a weekly basis and via personal meetings as requested.
Qualification Requirements:
  • University degree in land use management, agriculture, environmental science, or other relevant area.
  • Demonstrated mapping skills using QGIS.
  • Demonstrated web mapping and data visualizations, preferably with the proven skills in FieldPaper, Mapbox, TileMill, and CartoDB.
  • Experience with R, ENVI, C++ is an advantage.
  • Minimum of one year teaching or mentoring experience required.
  • Understanding and interest in development, economic and/or environmental issues a plus.
  • Strong commitment to objective and neutral “open data” standards.
  • Strong desire to promote Cambodia’s sustained development.
  • Willingness to respect EWMI-PRAJ principles and code of conduct.
Application information Interested candidates should submit a cover letter including a detailed CV with two references using the contact details below. Deadline for submitting applications is on 19 October, 2014 at 12 midnight. Women are encouraged to apply. Only short-listed candidates will be contacted. Applications will be accepted by email ONLY: recruitment@opendevcam.net

Wanted: Mapping/Data specialist

Open Development Cambodia (ODC) manages an open data website (www.opendevcam.net), aggregating a wide range of economic, environmental and social data to build out a development portrait of Cambodia.

Mapping/ Data specialist

Reports to:  Mapping Coordinator, Managing Editor, and Executive Director/ Editor in Chief Coordinates with: Mapping/Data specialist and other staff Primary Responsibilities Mapping/Data specialist: develops, designs and updates maps, data visualization and related graphical representations to illuminate development issues. This includes conducting research to identify and collect the data appropriate to upload and update the maps. Responsibilities & Tasks
  • Research and recommend sectorial, demographic, environmental, economic, and geographic areas for mapping and spatial/graphical representation. Research may be conducted online and at Ministries, NGOs, libraries, with other researchers, or in the field.
  • Collect data from public domain and then compile orderly geographical and non-geographical information for data storage.
  • Develop new maps for upload, spatial data, and graphical representations as assigned; applying ODC research, mapping, and editorial standards in English and Khmer.
  • Confer with web coding team to facilitate upload of varied data sets via graphical interface or mutually agreed formatting.
  • Be curious to learn newly developed technology pertinent to online mapping
  • Regularly and systematically research, update and maintain existing maps, graphical representations, and supporting data to ensure ODC maintains the most current data possible.
  • Through regular study, stay knowledgeable and skilled on research standards and relevant technical programs (including Open Street Map, Quantum GIS, Inkscape graphic design, and any open source software as needed) to stay up-to-date on developments.
  • Assist in image processing by using remote sensing software like ENVI for environmental monitoring
  • Identify technical problems and work with relevant ODC team members to solve them.
  • Participate in outreach to project partners, as assigned.
  • Assist with the administration of the Mapping Meet-Up and related activities.
  • Represent ODC at community functions, as assigned.
  • Perform other tasks, as needed or requested by the ODC Project Director.
  • Be able to work under pressure
Requirements
  • University degree; preferably in land use management, agriculture, environmental science, or other relevant area.
  • Demonstrated IT/Design skills, including use of web mapping and data visualization technologies such as FieldPapers, CartoDB, TileMill, Mapbox, Tableau Public, and Infogr.am.
  • Preferably, experience with data collection or processing tools such as Import.io, ScraperWiki, R, QGIS, and Google Refine.
  • Basic research skills, including online research.
  • General computer skills (word processing, spreadsheets, PowerPoint, internet search);
  • Understanding and interest in development, economic and/or environmental issues a plus.
  • Strong commitment to objective and neutral “open data” standards.
  • Strong desire to promote Cambodia’s sustained development.
  • Willingness to respect and work within EWMI-PRAJ principles, and EWMI and ODC code of conduct.
Application information: Interested candidates should submit a cover letter including a detailed CV with two references using the contact details below. Deadline for submitting applications is on 19 October, 2014 at 12 midnight. Women are encouraged to apply. Only short-listed candidates will be contacted. Applications will be accepted by email ONLY: recruitment@opendevcam.net

Wanted: Regional Information Technology Manager and Regional Data/Map Manager

Open Development Mekong (ODM) is the upcoming regional expansion of Open Development Cambodia (www.opendevcam.net), which provides access to environmental and socioeconomic information in various forms to encourage enlightened public discourse and policy-making. The ODM network will be a combined effort of partners in Vietnam, Thailand, Laos, and Myanmar to replicate the open access, open source model (for a preview, see www.opendevmekong.net). This requires a set of websites that share a unified data/content management platform for serving as a repository of news articles, maps, data visualizations, and legal and library materials in multiple languages. Coordination with the staff of partner organizations will also be key. To that end, ODM seeks a full-time Regional Data/Map Manager who can analyze and help others easily understand the information by producing visualizations and media.

Regional Information Technology Manager

Key Responsibilities
  1. Maintain the regional level platform, including ensuring that the site's server and other supporting systems are optimized for both back-end and front-end efficiency and security.
  2. Supervise the performance of the regional site and establish/meet benchmarks in comparison with national sites.
  3. Design technical improvements to bridge the various national sites, specifically to enhance:
    • user-friendliness (both internal and external users),
    • data visualization,
    • functionality of Geoserver and other web-mapping applications,
    • crowd-sourcing
  4. Train, guide and monitor country-level IT staff, in regard to their technical performance. Provide feedback on technical performance of country IT managers.
  5. Develop, revise, and update training materials, tools, templates and guides to support country-level IT managers, as needed or requested. Contribute to the development of similar material for non-technical staff, as needed.
  6. Facilitate the uploading and updating of data sets via graphical interface or other method that user-friendly for non-IT staff.
  7. Coordinate with and act as liaison to country-level IT managers to determine ongoing technical needs; understand overall site objectives to match technology with data/content priorities.
  8. Advise on technical feasibility of project targets, specifically relating to time expenditure and coding methods.
  9. Troubleshoot issues that arise in regional website maintenance and advise country-level partners in managing their technical setup. Identify areas in which additional technical support is needed and possible providers of such expertise.
  10. Supervise interns and volunteers contributing to technical work.
  11. Promote the OD Initiative and OD Mekong at outreach events, as assigned.
  12. Other tasks, as needed or directed.
Requirements:
  • Cambodian, Vietnamese, Thai, or Burmese nationals.
  • Degree in computer science or equivalent skills in coding, website development, and server management.
  • 5 years commercial or international development experience with large-scale website and database management, especially platforms such as CKAN, MySQL/PostgreSQL, WordPress, Linux, and Git as well as languages such as JavaScript and Python. Knowledge of other technologies including Jetty, Tomcat, Solr, Chef, Ansible, and Puppet.
  • Strong (IT) teaching, advising, and monitoring skills.
  • Demonstrated skills in mapping and data visualization a plus.
  • Proven ability to effectively troubleshoot technical problems and learn/teach new technologies as needed, especially for geospatial data.
  • Familiar with open data concepts and the associated community.
  • Self-motivated worker, who can operate effectively in a virtual workplace using GitHub and TeamworkPM.
  • Willingness to travel regionally and ability to work effectively with other cultures.
  • Strong English language skills, including writing (technical documentation, user manuals, etc.).
  • Preferably, native or equivalent competency in one or more regional languages (Khmer, Thai, Lao, Burmese, Chinese).
  • Preferably, understanding of and interest in regional development, economic, and/or environmental issues, and/or interest in open data.
  • Preferably, experience with user-centered site design and API/mobile development.

Regional Data/Map Manager

Key Responsibilities
  1. Collect, process, and publish data at the regional and country levels, across various topics or issue areas, ensuring that the OD websites contain a significant amount of high-quality, well-organized data sets.
  2. Scrape and aggregate public-domain data (government documents, nonprofit reports, etc.) by monitoring many sources to build up database while noting applicable licensing restrictions.
  3. Design infographics and visualizations to facilitate understanding and reuse of the data in several formats:
    • tabular (CSV/Excel files)
    • news articles, laws and library materials (text and PDF files)
    • geospatial (SHP/KML files and geotagged media)
    • images and videos (PNG and MP4 files)
  4. Train, guide and monitor country-level data publishers, in regard to their adhering to standards. Provide feedback on data management of country partners.
  5. Develop, revise, and update training materials, tools, templates and guides to support country-level data managers, as needed or requested. Contribute to the development of similar material for non-technical staff, as needed.
  6. Facilitate the creation and updating of data sets via software applications or online services that are user-friendly for non-technical staff and other users, such as data journalists.
  7. Coordinate with and act as liaison to other national teams for their data collection and processing; understand overall site objectives for matching to data/content priorities.
  8. Advise country-level partners in managing their data and coordinate with IT staff to troubleshoot technical issues that arise. Identify areas in which additional support is needed and possible providers of such expertise.
  9. Troubleshoot issues that arise in regional data management and advise country-level partners in managing their data. Identify areas in which additional technical support is needed and possible providers of such expertise.
  10. Supervise interns and volunteers contributing to data processing.
  11. PPromote the OD Initiative and OD Mekong at outreach events, as assigned./li>
  12. Other tasks, as needed or directed.
Requirements:
  • Vietnamese, Thai, Burmese, or Cambodian national
  • 5 years commercial or international development experience with large-scale content and data management, especially using platforms such as CKAN and WordPress.
  • Proven ability to effectively gather, process, and publish complex data and learn new methods or technologies as needed.
  • Preferably, experience with data collection or processing tools such as Import.io, ScraperWiki, R, QGIS, Google Refine, Tableau Public, and Infogr.am.
  • Proven ability to effectively troubleshoot data management problems and learn/teach new technologies as needed, especially for geospatial data.
  • Familiar with open data concepts, data journalism, and the associated community.
  • Self-motivated worker, who can operate effectively in a virtual workplace.
  • Willingness to travel regionally and ability to work effectively with other cultures.
  • Strong English language skills, including writing (technical documentation, user manuals, etc.).
  • Preferably, native or equivalent competency in one or more regional languages (Khmer, Thai, Lao, Burmese, Chinese).
  • Preferably, understanding of and interest in regional development, economic, and/or environmental issues.
Application information Interested candidates should submit a cover letter including a detailed CV with two references using the contact details below. Deadline for submitting applications is on 7 October, 2014 at 12 midnight. Women are encouraged to apply. Only short-listed candidates will be contacted. Applications will be accepted by email ONLY: recruitment@opendevmekong.net Also see www.opendevmekong.net/jobs and www.opendevcam.net/jobs.

SPATIAL PLANNING LAB PROJECT

Term of Reference

Job title:Mapping Instructor (part-time) Reports to:ODC Research & Volunteer Coordinator, ODC Mapping Coordinator and Executive Director/ Editor-in-Chief Coordinates with:Spatial Planning Lab project partners, ODC staff Background/Context: Spatial planning and land management requires multidisciplinary expertise. Planners, in order to perform their tasks effectively and ensure that land is managed in sustainable manner must learn not only about administrative and legal frameworks, mapping and zoning. They also need to learn how to protect the people from natural and man- made disasters such as flooding, landslides, pollution, etc and ensure access to basic social services and livelihoods opportunities. In order to build peaceful and, resilient communities and nation, it is essential to put people and their rights at the heart of the spatial planning process. Far too often, spatial decisions contribute to exclusion of vulnerable and marginalized groups, favoring unsustainable but profitable land uses. The role of spatial planners is to identify win-win solutions for all stakeholders to ensure Cambodia’s economic development while not violating human rights of its citizens. Spatial Planning Lab is carried out over a 6-month period and includes 3 components: (1). Geographic Information System (GIS) Lab: One 3-hour session weekly and some field trips, to be conducted by ODC GIS Instructor. (2). Spatial Planning Lecture Series and Workshops: One 2 or 3-hour session bi-weekly, to be facilitated by PIN. (3). Research/Technical Consultation: One 30-minute session after each lecture or workshop in component 2, to be facilitated by PIN and/or ODC. The three components compliment each other and are designed to provide a holistic learning experience for the future land use planners and encourages them to draw connections between theory and practice. The GIS Lab emphasizes skill training and hands-on technical applications. The Spatial Planning Lecture Series and Workshops have been designed to raise awareness of the future land use planning in relation to spatial challenges such as Climate Change, Disaster Risk Reduction, Gender and Inclusive and Participatory Spatial Development respecting Royal Government of Cambodia planning framework.The Research/Technical Consultation sessions provide thesis-writing students with informal guidance and feedback on their spatial planning related research and technical analysis. Call for Applications Open Development Cambodia seeks a part-time mapping instructor (32hrs from November 1, 2014 to December 31, 2014) to teach the GIS Lab component of the Spatial Planning Lab. The purpose of this lab is to provide students practial applications in spatial planning excercises using  Geographic Information System, remote sensing principles, web mapping  technology, and open data from Cambodia. Primary Responsibilities Develops lesson plans and conducts the GIS Lab including, but not limited to, fieldworks conducted by the project partners. Ensure linkages between the Lecture Series component of the Spatial Planning Lab and
  • Develop a 32-hour curriculum according to students’s skills and needs.
  • Conduct GIS training; ensuing that the GIS Lab excercises corresponds to the Lecture Series, to be conducted by People in Need, and Open Development Cambodia’s projects, as requested by ODC Mapping Coordinator.
  • Research and/or confere with ODC Mapping Coordinator to identify relavant sectoral, demographic, environmental, economic, and geographic areas for mapping and spatial/graphical representation needed for the excercises.
  • Ensure that maps and other infographics meet ODC publishing standard and are supported with appropriate and complete metadata.
  • Oversee project fieldworks and test the ODC Mapping Kit with students as requested.
  • Document teaching materials and outputs to be shared with project partners.
  • Conduct two assessment tests with students; measure their perofrmance.
  • Produce a written report on the GIS Lab relecting the contractin periods.
  • Update the ODC Reserach & Volunteer Coordinator/ODC Mapping Coordinator on project developments via e-mail on a weekly basis and via personal meetings as requested.
Qualification Requirements:
  • University degree in land use management, agriculture, environmental science, or other relevant area.
  • Demonstrated mapping skills using QGIS.
  • Demonstrated web mapping and data visualizations, preferably with the proven skills in FieldPaper, Mapbox, TileMill, and CartoDB.
  • Experience with R, ENVI, C++ is an advantage.
  • Minimum of one year teaching or mentoring experience required.
  • Understanding and interest in development, economic and/or environmental issues a plus.
  • Strong commitment to objective and neutral “open data” standards.
  • Strong desire to promote Cambodia’s sustained development.
  • Willingness to respect EWMI-PRAJ principles and code of conduct.
Application information Interested candidates should submit a cover letter including a detailed CV with two references using the contact details below. Deadline for submitting applications is on 19 October, 2014 at 12 midnight. Women are encouraged to apply. Only short-listed candidates will be contacted. Applications will be accepted by email ONLY: recruitment@opendevcam.net

item.title: Localization
item.dc:creator: odc
item.content:encoded:
Open Development Cambodia (ODC) was originally designed as an English-language web resource. In order to expand our reach to new audiences, and offer greater access to Cambodians and Khmer-language users, ODC is currently working on translating the website into Khmer. As of February, 2014, several pages have been translated into Khmer. You can start exploring the Khmer site by visiting its homepage. Over time, most of the site will be translated. If you have questions, comments, or constructive feedback, please submit them to contact@opendevcam.net. We appreciate your interest and your patience as we continue to make the ODC website functional and powerful to as many people as possible.

គេហទំព័រ​ទិន្នន័យ​អំពី​ការអភិវឌ្ឍ ហៅ​កាត់​ថា​អូ​ឌី​ស៊ី (ODC) ត្រូវបាន​បង្កើតឡើង​ពី​ដំបូង​ជា​ភាសា​អង់គ្លេស​។ ដើម្បី​ពង្រីក​ការផ្សព្វផ្សាយ​របស់​យើង​ឲ្យបាន​ដល់​ទស្សនិកជន​ថ្មីៗ​បន្ថែមទៀត និង​ផ្តល់​ព័ត៌មាន​ឲ្យបាន​កាន់តែ​ទូលំទូលាយ​ថែម​ទៀត​ដល់​ប្រជាពលរដ្ឋ​កម្ពុជា​និង​អ្នក​ប្រើ​ភាសា​ខ្មែរ អង្គការ​អូ​ឌី​ស៊ី បច្ចុប្បន្ន​កំពុង​ធ្វើការ​បកប្រែ​គេហទំព័រ​នេះ​ពី​ភាសា​អង់គ្លេស​ទៅ​ជា​ភាសា​ខ្មែរ​។ នៅ​ខែ​កុម្ភៈ ឆ្នាំ​២០១៤ ទំព័រ​មួយចំនួន​ត្រូវបាន​បកប្រែ​ជា​ភាសា​ខ្មែរ​។ លោកអ្នក​អាច​ចាប់ផ្តើម ធ្វើការ​ស្រាវជ្រាវ​នៅ​ក្នុង​គេហទំព័រ​ជា​ភាសា​ខ្មែរ ដោយ​ចូល​ទស្សនា​នៅក្នុង​តំណ​ភ្ជាប់​នេះ ។ រយះពេល​ប៉ុន្មាន​ខែ​ខាងមុខនេះ ទំព័រ​ផ្សេងៗ​ទៀត​ស្ទើរតែ​ទាំងអស់​នឹង​ត្រូវ​បាន​ប​ក​ប្រែ​រួច ។ ប្រសិន​បើ​លោក​អ្នក​មាន បញ្ហា ឬ​មាន​មតិ​យោបល់ ឬ​ការរិះគន់​ក្នុងន័យ​ស្ថាបនា សូម​ផ្ញើ​សំនួរ​តាមរយៈ contact@opendevcam.net​។ យើងខ្ញុំ​សូម​កោតសរសើរ​និង​ផ្តល់​តម្លៃ​ខ្ពស់​ចំពោះ​ចំណាប់អារម្មណ៍ និង​ការអត់ធ្មត់​របស់លោក​អ្នក ខណៈពេល​ដែល​យើងខ្ញុំ​បន្ត​ធ្វើឲ្យ​គេហទំព័រ​អូឌី​ស៊ី (ODC) មាន​ដំណើរការ និង​សន្ទុះ​ទៅមុខ​តាមតែ​អាចធ្វើ​បាន​ជូន​ដល់​ប្រជាពលរដ្ឋ​ជាច្រើនរូប​។​

item.title: Download Maps
item.dc:creator: odc_admin
item.content:encoded: Maps are available on Open Development Cambodia. They may be freely accessed and downloaded. Downloads are available in multiple formats (PDF, KML, Shapefile). Open Development Cambodia map collection includes economic land concessions, mining, hydropower, and much much more.

item.title: Disclaimer
item.dc:creator: odc_admin
item.content:encoded: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported License. Article summaries are copyrighted by their respective sources. This Open Development Cambodia (ODC) site is compiled from available documentation and provides data without fee for general informational purposes only. It is not a commercial research service. Information is posted only after a careful vetting and verification process, however ODC cannot guarantee accuracy, completeness or reliability from third party sources in every instance. Site users are encouraged to do additional research in support of their activities and to share the results of that research with our team at info@opendevcam.net to further improve site accuracy. In deference to Cambodian law, Open Development Cambodia (ODC) site users understand and agree to take full responsibility for reliance on any site information provided and to hold harmless and waive any and all liability against individuals or entities associated with its development, form and content for any loss, harm or damage suffered as a result of its use.ខ្លឹមសារ​នៅក្នុង​គេហទំព័រ​នេះ​ត្រូវបាន​ផ្តល់​ក្រោម​អាជ្ញាប័ណ្ណ​ Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported License។ ​អត្ថបទ​ព័ត៌មាន​សង្ខេប​ត្រូវបាន​រក្សា​សិទ្ធិ​ដោយ​ប្រភព​នៃ​អត្ថបទ​ទាំងនោះ​។ គេហទំព័រ Open Development Cambodia (ODC)​ប្រមូលផ្តុំ​នូវ​ឯកសារ​នានា ហើយ​ផ្តល់​ជូន​នូវ​ទិន្នន័យ​ដោយ​មិន​គិតថ្លៃ ក្នុង​គោលបំណង​ជា​ព័ត៌មាន​ទូទៅ​ប៉ុណ្ណោះ​។ គេហទំព័រ​នេះ មិនមែន​ជា​សេវាកម្ម​ដើម្បី​ប្រាក់ចំណេញ​ទេ​។ ព័ត៌មាន​ត្រូវ​បាន​បោះ​ផ្សាយ បន្ទាប់​ពី​ការមើល​បញ្ជាក់ និង​ផ្ទៀងផ្ទាត់​យ៉ាង​ហ្មត់ចត់​។ យ៉ាងណាក៏ដោយ អូ​ឌី​ស៊ី​មិនអាច​ធានា​នូវ​ភាពត្រឹមត្រូវ ពេញលេញ ឬ​ភាព​ដែល​អាច​ទុកចិត្តបាន​នៃ​ប្រភព​ភាគី​ទី​បី​ក្នុង​គ្រប់​ករណី​ទាំងអស់​បាន​ទេ​។ យើង​សូម​លើកទឹកចិត្ត​អ្នកប្រើប្រាស់​គេហទំព័រ​នេះ​ឲ្យធ្វើ​ការស្រាវជ្រាវ​បន្ថែម ហើយ​ចែករម្លែក​នូវ​លទ្ធផល​នៃ​ការស្រាវជ្រាវ​នេះ​ជាមួយនិង​ក្រុម​របស់​យើង​តាម​អាស័យដ្ឋាន​នេះ info@opendevcam.net ដើម្បី​ជួយ​លើកកម្ពស់​ភាព ត្រឹមត្រូវ​របស់​គេហទំព័​រ​។ ស្រប​ទៅតាម​ច្បាប់​របស់​ប្រទេស​កម្ពុជា អ្នកប្រើប្រាស់​គេហទំព័រ​Open Development Cambodia (ODC) យល់​និង​ព្រមព្រៀង​ថា​នឹង​ទទួលខុសត្រូវ​ទាំងស្រុង​ចំពោះ​ការពឹងផ្អែក​ទៅលើ​ព័ត៌មាន​ណាមួយ​របស់​គេហទំព័រ ហើយ​មិន​ត្រូវ​ផ្ទុកផ្តាក់​ការទទួលខុសត្រូវ​ទៅលើ​បុគ្គល​ឬ​ស្ថាប័ន​ដែល​មាន​ការពាក់ព័ន្ធ​នឹង​ការផលិត​ព័ត៌មាន​នេះ ចំពោះ​ការខាតបង់ ខូចខាត ឬ​អន្តរាយ​ណាមួយ​ដែល​កើតចេញ​ដោយសារ​ការប្រើប្រាស់​ព័ត៌មាន​ទាំងនេះ​ឡើយ​។​
